required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: No Power Bionic Lower Extremity Prosthesis
clinical_study.official_title: No Power Bionic Lower Extremity Prosthesis

brief_summary.textblock: A prosthesis that requires no power, yet has the functionality to perform various tasks, including those needed in the military, is extremely important. To bridge the gap between passive and powered prostheses, this study will test the Compliant Adaptive Energy Storage and Return (CAESAR) foot. The investigators will test and improve this foot design mechanically, and then test this design on individuals with lower limb amputation in a lab setting. The goal of this project is to develop a passive foot that can ultimately provide the user with more normalized biomechanics and function during ambulatory tasks.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants will walk with their standard prosthesis and then the new design of CAESAR foot

primary_outcome.measure: Compare Peak Ankle Power between CAESAR Foot and Dynamic Response Foot
primary_outcome.time_frame: during one lab visit, approximately four hours

primary_outcome.measure: Compare Ankle Range of Motion between CAESAR Foot and Dynamic Response Foot
primary_outcome.time_frame: during one lab visit, approximately four hours
primary_outcome.description: Joint angles will be calculated using a motion capture system with a six degree of freedom marker set applied to the lower extremities.

secondary_outcome.measure: Compare Metabolic Cost of Walking between CAESAR Foot and Dynamic Response Foot
secondary_outcome.time_frame: during one lab visit, approximately four hours
secondary_outcome.description: The metabolic cost of transport (COT) will be calculated for the dynamic response foot and CAESAR foot using the K4B2 Cosmed system.

arm_group.description: In this condition, participants will walk with their standard prosthetic foot

In this condition, participants will walk with a new prosthesis with enhanced energy storage and return and increased range of motion. They will only wear this device in the lab for an approximately 4 hour period of time

intervention.intervention_name: Compliant Adaptive Energy Storage and Return Foot
intervention.description: The primary concept of the CAESAR foot is to capture the energy at heel strike and then store it to be released at a later time when it can provide additional propulsive forces during walking. Each transtibial amputee will wear the CAESAR foot and perform various tasks in the lab.
This is a commercial prosthetic foot that has been prescribed to the individual

criteria.textblock:
Patient Population:
Inclusion Criteria:
- At least 18 years old
- Transtibial amputation of one leg
- Classified as K3 or K4 on the Medicare Functional Classification Level
- Use of a well-fitting prosthetic socket with dynamic response foot for at least 6 months
Exclusion Criteria:
- Significant injury to intact limb
- History of balance impairments or neurologic disorders
- Significant cardiovascular or respiratory disease
